customData.content: 40-year-old male patient presented with intermittent chest pain and discomfort for one month. The pain was located on the right side of the sternum, about the size of a palm, and was not significantly relieved after rest. The patient reported no cough, sputum, throat irritation, fever, or significant weight change in the past six months.

HPI.summary: 40-year-old male with intermittent chest pain and discomfort for one month.

customData.content: Patient denies pet exposure, special dust exposure, smoking history, drinking history, recent travel, and recent dental work. Vitals: Temperature 36.5°C, pulse rate 84 bpm, respiration 20 breaths/min, blood pressure 114/75 mmHg.

Chest pain symptoms are somewhat relieved by oral Ibuprofen, but it quickly receded. Chest CT scan revealed a 3.8 cm space occupying lesion in the upper lobe of the right lung with clear boundaries and uneven internal density. Radiologist suggests it may be a benign lesion, possibly a haematoma.

imaging.body_part: Upper lobe of the right lung
imaging.finding: 3.8 cm space occupying lesion in the upper lobe of the right lung with clear boundaries and uneven internal density
imaging.impression: may be a benign lesion, possibly a haematoma

customData.content: 16-slice computed tomographic scan showed a mass image in the upper lobe of the right lung adjacent to the chest wall. The tubercle boundary was clear and the internal density was uneven. Careful examination showed that the mass had a pedicle. Lung lesion diagnosed as a schwannoma.

imaging.body_part: Upper lobe of the right lung
imaging.finding: Mass with clear tubercle boundary and uneven internal density, pedicle present

customData.content: Needle biopsy confirmed the lesion as a schwannoma. The fine needle puncture procedure was smooth, with no complications such as bleeding or pneumothorax.

procedures.outcome: no complications such as bleeding or pneumothorax

customData.content: Patient underwent video-assisted thoracic surgery in an outside hospital but was lost to follow-up. Histologic diagnosis from the mass confirmed schwannoma.

Histopathology of resected mass shows: Microscopic histological examination demonstrated the presence of proliferating Schwann cells characterized by spindle-shaped nuclei and pointed ends. Immunohistochemistry: S100+, CD34+, EMA+, CD56+, CD117, Calretinin+, Vimentin+, Desmin-, smooth muscle antigen-

data.content: Transition from initial presentation to vital signs and negative history.

Chest CT scan revealed a 3.8 cm space occupying lesion in the upper lobe of the right lung with clear boundaries and uneven internal density. Radiologist suggests it may be a benign lesion, possibly a haematoma. Symptoms are somewhat relieved by oral Ibuprofen, but it quickly receded.

Further imaging with 16-slice computed tomographic scan showed a mass image in the upper lobe of the right lung adjacent to the chest wall. The tubercle boundary was clear and the internal density was uneven. Careful examination showed that the mass had a pedicle. Lung lesion diagnosed as a schwannoma.
Needle biopsy confirmed the lesion as a schwannoma. The fine needle puncture procedure was smooth, with no complications such as bleeding or pneumothorax.
Patient underwent video-assisted thoracic surgery in an outside hospital but was lost to follow-up. Histologic diagnosis from the mass confirmed schwannoma.

Histopathology of resected mass shows: Microscopic histological examination demonstrated the presence of proliferating Schwann cells characterized by spindle-shaped nuclei and pointed ends. Immunohistochemistry: S100+, CD34+, EMA+, CD56+, CD117, Calretinin+, Vimentin+, Desmin-, smooth muscle antigen-
